posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Who is /fat/ for?
For marshmallow men who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

>CICO is unsustainable and doesn't work. Pic related.
That statement makes no fucking sense. It literally is calories in and calories out for weight loss.

I'm not saying zero carb doesn't work. I'm saying it doesn't work if you're also strength training. I hope everyone tries a zero carb diet while training, see where that gets them. Well,it will probably still work great for them if they're a novice. If you are an intermediate or greater lifter, you will absolutely feel the performance hit when cutting out carbs.

>>69531365
>What if I just want to get lean and look good, then what should I eat?

From my own experience, you need to maintain close to 1gr of protein per lb of lean body mass, go on a 500 calorie deficit per day, and those calories will come entirely from fat and carbs anyways. More so once you increase your protein intake. For overall health, wellness, and recovery, make sure you get all the foods you need for a good diet. I made another post about my college days diet in another thread, mostly lamb, mushrooms, onions, spinach, broccoli, beans, and fruits like berries. That will hit all the little micronutrient goals. If you're lazy or cheap, you can even meet calorie and protein goals by chugging down like 400 calories of protein powder and water to get like 50g or protein.

Just get a balanced diet with tons of protein. Lower calories to lose the weight, don't expect it to be fast, don't think about it too much past that. You aren't some morbidly obese fuck, so a normal human being diet will work. Maybe this keto guy is 100% right that it helps morbidly obese people but idk, seems like a lacking and temporary diet.

CICO is a hoax diet created by the sugar industry. It's based on biology denialism. It suggests that macronutrients in the body don't have different biological effects aside from their calorie value.

Of course today we know for certain this isn't true. Carbs promote hunger and fat storage. Protein promotes muscle growth. Fat promotes satiety and high metabolism. Macronutrients are all different (obviously).

If you do something insane like eating carbs and counting calories, you cause metabolic slowdown because the body is trying to keep stored fat.

>>69531780
CICO is a good rule of thumb but is a physicist take on a biological issue.
There is no perfect exchange of calories, your gut bacteria extracts the calories from the food, and its composition varies among individuals.
Obese people have over-effective gut bacteria (the same king of gut bacteria cocktail found in third trimester pregnant women), they extract more calories from the same amount of food because they are more efficient at it.
So CICO doesn't determine everything, it's more of a ballpark estimate.

So /fat/,

For a year I had been going to the gym on and off, in various states of activity: Months of going hard, months of nothing. Mostly due to the demoralisation of being shit at dieting and not controlling cravings.

This is not the first time I've had to drop weight, maybe 5 years ago I went from fat to jacked in the span of a couple years then covid hit and fucked it all up when everything shut for two years. I assumed it'd only be for a few months so everything just spiralled.

But somehow some things changed, I've found the discipline I had the first time around, that I have been lacking in my recent attempts. The will to say no refined sugars, 3 reasonable meals a day, no alcohol, no snacks, no exceptions. I finally figured out for the second time that saying "just this once" is what fucks the whole thing up.

End blog post, but maybe that'll hell someone else get it together. It's never just this once.

Unrelated to manlet remodeling: I had an external fixator on my ulna when I was younger to lengthen the bone due to a growth plate fracture. They split the bone being lengthened in the middle and lengthen the fixator a few times a day to keep it separated. The bone heals normally like it was broken. Obviously you have to be careful right after removing it, but after another 6-8 weeks after it's pretty much good to go.

The fixator is held in place with screws that protrude from your bone, oddly enough you can't feel it when they unscrew them at the end.

Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.
Follow any temporary fad diet - if you can't maintain the diet, you won't keep the weight off.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

women have ~12x less test than men
they still get hair loss just in different patterns(all over their head including their eyebrows and eyelashes) and not to mention they also have considerably less DHT, so nothing of what you say is of any significance because you don't know what's causing hairloss or what's correlated the most with hairloss which doesn't even tell you anything in itself because there are men that are born with no 5 alpha reductase enzyme activity yet have normal-high testosterone levels and have perma baby hairlines until they die of old age
the reason? genetics+DHT
your skin itself has 5 alpha reductase enzyme activity and its density is genetically determined, it's in the scalp and skin itself that testosterone is converted to DHT which is why it's a problem
tigers have more test than you and they never get bald + they are stressed from only eating once every few days and parasitic infection
why? genetics, their skin simply doesn't have the amount of 5 alpha reductase enzyme activity or density we have so it doesn't matter how much testosterone or even DHT and other androgens they produce, it's their genetics.

>if oyu block all test you see lack of hair loss.
you can't crash all your test production to 0 and even if you could doing so crashes your DHT to a value much closer to 0 so you still don't know what's promoting (and specially not causing) hairloss

At the top of this hill, the air is cold. Bitter wind bites my face as I vomit into the snow. I light fire and breath smoke. I plant my banner and I sit down, spinning a chrysalis that nobody can see. In this womb I grow, divide, and adapt.

I have never felt more human, more man. I am gold covered by the mud as a sapling springs up among it, forming the shimmering heart in a mighty oak. I am marble being chipped away by the highest master of creation.

There is no rush, only deliberate purpose chipped away every day as a canyon is deepened by the waters of life.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My faith is an anvil, my soul glows red with from fires of the divine armorer. Every blow struck by his hammer is a test of the steel I am forged in; molding and taking shape of a holy blade, to vanquish every demon that dare intrude upon consecrated ground.

I am the leather shaped by the hand of Christ into the device he used to drive evil from the temple. It is not wrath lashing out, it is the firm, correcting hand of love.

Cadia stands, motherfuckers.

Stand tall my brothers and sisters, fly your standards, sing clearly through the dark nights and light your torches to guide your lost siblings home.

I have a theory, and it's a kind of fanciful notion but based in reality, that I fully accept may be larp, but that if you eat super healthy, I'm talking about fruit and veg every day, and you don't get fat, you don't eat rubbish/drink a lot of alcohol, and you keep living a healthy lifestyle by exercise etc., that you won't get fat as you get older.

The reason why it's based in reality is because fatties tend to pile the pounds on over the years gradually and once they reach a certain weight, they typically can't go back. "insulin resistance" caused by bad eating has been pointed to as being a big part of this. So the theory would be that if you escape from this insulin resistance you can get old while keeping fat down pretty much the same or very similar as when young, even if your metabolism does go down there's no reason why your appetite shouldn't also - there's definitely a slice of the population that does stay thin all throughout their lives. If you look at female actresses whose job it is to stay thin - lots and lots can stay thin.

The theory may still be a stretch cause there are lots of old thin people who eat like this, but something to think about next time you're stuffing your face with pizza or ice cream that it might be slowly causing your body to pile on the pounds.

this is the actual answer. it is built into our bodies. our biology has some general understanding of "finding a mate" mode vs. "dad" mode.

our urges suddenly change when we are a father and constantly around a pregnant woman or constantly around a newborn baby. people try and come up with cultural shit or psychological shit but it's actually a pretty mechanical thing that happens to your hormones.

it becomes culture because it happens to so many humans that they develop words for it, jokes about it, it becomes a meme (literal meme, not internet meme). but it becomes a cultural thing because it is in everyone's biology.

this is why you have to be obsessed with fitness, to overcome what your body is telling you to do. the same way you have to be obsessed with eating a clean diet to maintain a clean diet if suddenly someone gave you "hunger" pills. it is doable, but it requires a lot of willpower to keep lifting because your testosterone will drop and your capacity for aggression will drop.

this is why the people who stay fit as mothers and fathers are people who have already been fit for a long time, they are the only ones with the habits deep-seated enough in their brains to overcome the natural urges to slow things down a bit and to keep grinding in the gym. to "rage against the dying of the light".

everyone wants their unique answer to be the answer because they want to get their social commentary out there, but it turns out this is the actual answer. it's a simple mechanical process.

posts.com:
Muscle mass is a fantastic calorie sink. Gained muscle is expensive for the body to create, and it doesn't give it up easy. It takes years of lethargy to lose it all, and even the occasional heavy workout helps a lot. Your body's ability to hormonally regulate muscle amount wanes with age, which is where the misconception of "a slower metabolism" comes from. Relative metabolism remains the same throughout life, and lifestyle changes with adult responsibilities taking up many people's time.
It's all excuses in the end. People get comfortable, which is ironic as strength and health promise a much more comfortable aging process and life.

>>69529563
Everything you said is correct. Even if you were to drink three energy drinks a day and only eat candy, you will lose weight provided you are in a caloric deficit. People have actually done similar experiments on themselves to prove this.

But the term "weight loss" became confused with "fat loss".
Losing weight is not necessarily losing fat, people who follow the CICO principle can be disappointed to find that the 10kg they lost was mostly muscle, and in fact their bodyfat% has gone UP because they lost muscle faster than they lost fat. This could be due to not having enough protein in the diet or not doing enough resistance training, however there are so many other factors in body composition that it could be many other things such as a micronutrient deficiency. People who wish to lose fat without losing too much muscle are best advised to maintain a high protein intake, continue doing resistance training (even though they will probably lose strength over the cut) and eat almost completely whole, natural and micronutrient dense foods.

That said, someone who is simply obese can absolutely follow the CICO principle while still eating the shitty, ultra-processed foods they have become accustomed to and still see good weight loss. For an obese person who doesn't care about being an athlete or eating healthy (yet) eating anything will work because they just want to become thin, not maintain muscle; it also makes it easier for an obese person to follow a diet when they're still allowed to drink coke and eat cupcakes.

I've run Chicago and New York. I haven't run Boston despite living ten minutes from the start line. (Still not fast enough to qualify. Still need to find 8 minutes.)
The majors are as much a carnival as they are a race. Never target one for a PB. Just getting to the start line is a huge undertaking. When you run one, it's best, I think to be sure to drink in the atmosphere and accept you're doing a part of something huge. They're so much fun, though. You meet so many people, everyone's having a great time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69520193
I know that temptation, anon. It's a combination of boredom, competitive instinct, and desire to fast track improvement. These impulses can be addressed with Stoicism or Mindfulness Meditation, because these impulses are controllable once understood.

Imagine yourself on your next jog. What is your goal? Are you competing? Are you trying to gradually improve health? Do you seek entertainment? Once you define this goal (for me it is gradual improvement) then you'll recognize conflicting impulses and you'll have a chance to resist them (I resist the urge to accelerate). So you went slower than you wanted. So you were bored at times. So what? When you got home, you got the reward of improved health and had no dread of doing it again.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69524674
Correct. That low heart rate encourages capillary growth and trains the body to become more efficient at transporting and using oxygen. The process can take months, though.
But once you're there, then when you push it during a race or time trial, you'll be able to leverage that efficiency by being able to sustain a high heart rate for longer.

That's the difference between people who run a sub-40 minute 10k and those who can't: it's not the speed they're running, it's how long they can sustain it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69524674
How old are you?
Yes, pace will improve over time (can be frustratingly slow progress). Don't just run at one pace though (shorter stuff a bit quicker but not too fast to begin with) or you will become a one pace runner.
One thing often not discussed here is that as you improve, you can tweak slow run HR upwards a bit and that your threshold hr pace will go up as well (only reliable way of checking this is with a blood test). Will require a bit of reading and experimentation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69524806
29, started running just under 2 months ago.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69524868
2 months. Well, that's not long to see a lot of improvement. That takes a long time. I seem to remember that mitochondrial adaptation for a specific training load takes about 8 weeks (maybe a bit more) which is one reason why old school training used to be based on 4 or 8 week blocks: 3 or 6 weeks build up and hold, 1 or 2 weeks easy, then another block with an increased overall load. I used to work well on 6+2 for base training and 3+1 for summer.
130 for z1 is a reasonable starting point for a 29 yr old. Be aware that not everyone has an mhr that follows the formula (I couldn't get any higher than 195 aged 18) so might be worth trying to work out what that is a little down the line (note attainable hr also differs across sports, slightly different concept). Some he monitors (eg Polar) can do a test that gives a good estimate.

posts.com:
>>69526979
They are very good for identifying when you are coming down with something nasty that you haven't noticed (elevated heart rate at a slow pace etc) or if you haven't recovered properly from the previous hard session.

They are great for roadwork if you have trouble identifying your threshold effort. Also great for telling you when things are going haywire and you haven't noticed (or need the point reinforced).

Some good athletes are terrible at knowing when they are overcooking things (guilty) - HRM very useful.

I maintain that they are SFA use on the athletics track where you are typically working to a particular pace (seriously, who checks their HR doing fast repeat 200s, 400s, 800s whatever). This is where my comment about post session WTF (diagnostic) came from.

Also XC racing - unlikely at the sharp end...

I ran with one olympian (marathon) studied later on with another (female LD track Oly) and ran with some guys that ran in Euros and Commonwealth champs. To the best of my knowledge, none of them used HRMs. Okay 15-20 years ago but the tech was mature by then and not niche (I started 94 with a borrowed polar).

Now triathletes and cyclists, well...

>what's in it and where do i get it?
It's regular asthma medication.

A lot of the time it's not doping per se, but abusing a system called TUE (therapeutic use exemption). If you have a legitimate medical condition, then you can compete while taking a medicine that you would otherwise not be allowed to. The athletes get unscrupulous doctors to diagnose them with asthma, then they are permitted to use asthma medication in competition.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So I bought a pair of meme shoes. Asics Superblast. 45.5mm of stack in the heel! (8mm drop, though I'm a forefoot striker so drop is irrelevant to me.)

I was expecting them to be shit and return them but holy shit, these are actually really good. They're not pillow-soft; they're actually pretty stiff but they have great energy return and they're much more stable than normal high-stack shoes.
I've run about 55 miles in them so far at all sorts of distances and paces and these things can do any kind of training. High tempo, easy runs, long, short, strides, intervals, you name it.
The upper is comfortable, the shoe is surprisingly light, the outsole has good grip, and it's pretty thick so it should last a while.

These are my new favorite training shoe. These for training, Vaporfly for racing, I'll never need another road shoe.

While that's definitely easing in, I guess the fact that the pain started right after you extended jogging duration could indicate that it wasn't easing in enough for any number of reasons (maybe you're overweight, or your joints are that unused to exertion, or your diet sucks, or you have a genetic limitation, etc.)
My suggestion is to watch the video, take a screenshot and put it on your desktop as a reminder, and after your ankle heals up, go for a much easier jog in which you focus on getting that form down.

I'm a true believer due to the fact that I'm improving rapidly over the last few weeks after getting form right. Long ago I was a heel striker and running was miserable (ankle pain). Recently I was using marginal form (correctly landing on forefoot, incorrectly reaching legs ahead of body) and running was miserable. Now I'm getting to a fourth mile and becoming bored, which is cooler than being hurt or exhausted.

Seems like you're being pretty smart about it. Hopefully just need optimization and acclimatization.

After the trip I started to realize I have been living a lie all along. I have been eating food not made for me, breathing air not meant for me and living a life without taking care of myself. If I could summarize the whole trip in one word it would be: CARE.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69506296
>>69506401
If you genuinely don't want to kill yourself then you're going to be fine. Like the other anon said, in order to be a mentally ill fuckup on drugs you usually also need to be a mentally ill fuckup when you're sober, and if you're a schizo or serious mental illness runs in your family then you shouldn't do psychedelics (or other drugs) period. Stories about people leaping out windows thinking they can fly or peeling off their skin because they think they're an orange are just DARE bullshit. If you're a reasonable stable person taking a reasonable dose in a safe place (i.e don't do it in public, do it in your own home or a friend's place) you'll be fine. The biggest risk with psychedelics isn't physically harming yourself, it's having a bad trip on a really high dose and feeling complete mental despair for (what feels like) a really long time until you either manage to calm yourself down or the drug starts wearing off. I've had bad trips where I literally thought I was dead, or in a coma and being operated on and in those moments I was very conscious about my physical well-being and made sure not to damage my body, it's more of a mental thing.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69508988
They can give you a eureka moment that drastically change your attitude towards life, yourself and your habits, but for some people it's just a recreational drug that allows them to experience the world differently for a while, some people have bad trips and feel like shit for a while. They're not a magical pill you swallow to cure depression though. Clinical studies have shown very good results with addiction for smokers and anxiety about death for patients with cancer, they're also hopeful it'll be a good tool against depression but you have to keep in mind that's a guided trip session where you have professionals with you to help you make sense of all your thoughts while tripping. You can give it a try to see if you like it, just don't go in expecting it to fix all your problems.

>>69514707
Don't take more than you can handle (if you don't know your limit then start small and work your way up in increments), trip in a safe space (i.e your home, don't be a retard and take it in public) and have a laid back, accepting attitude towards things. Bad trips are just nasty thoughts in your head. The more you think about them and try to force them out of your head, the worse they get. It's like trying not to think about an elephant after somebody tells you not to think about an elephant. Accept that the thought exists in your head and it doesn't really mean anything unless you decide that it does. Once it's no longer 'taboo' it stops being an intrusive thought and you'll forget about it as soon as you get distracted by something else, which happens real fast on psychedelics.

>but ever since I had a bad trip (solipsistic crisis, realized my entire reality could be fake and I could be a lonely God)
Why does that make you unhappy? Is it the idea that it genuinely isn't real even if it feels real? What you live in and perceive is your reality, even if it isn't 'real'. It's real to you, this is the life you live. In this reality you have the freedom to pursue hobbies, friendship and love. You have senses that feel great to stimulate, whether that's eating good food, listening to music, viewing beautiful works of art or being caressed by someone you care about. I've had bad trips where I've come to the realization that I'm actually dead and everything I experience is just a cope by my brain which doesn't want to stop existing, and I've had bad trips where I got stuck in an infinite looping cycle. They were truly terrifying thoughts until I accepting that if this was the case then there's absolutely nothing I can do about it. Even then, if I was truly dead or had gone insane, I wasn' in any pain or discomfort. Quite the opposite, I was very comfortable in the safety of my own home, had I been hungry I could have eaten, had I wanted to I could have left that place if I felt it was like a prison - but I didn't. The more I thought about it as an opportunity to have a good time the less anxious I felt. Even if I am dead and you are a lonely schizo god we can still do the things we like doing. An eternity here is only a curse if you don't enjoy your stay.

Part of it is the way psychedelics fuck with your hormones/emotions. Imagine being really happy, like the joy you felt as a kid opening a christmas present from your parents. The anticipation building up over the previous few days, the warmth and love you felt knowing that a lot of thought and consideration went into their gift, that they want you to be happy and excited. Idk what the gift was or what the year was, but odds are you had a christmas just like I'm talking about, and this is why you remember it. The emotional impact solidifies the memory and gives it significance to you.

Now imagine you're just chilling on the couch listening to music and feel that same emotion amplified 100x but for absolutely no reason other than you having eaten some mushrooms an hour earlier... suddenly that Tool song on the radio is feeling extremely meaningful and significant... and your mind is struggling to find the correlation between the thoughts and emotions you are experiencing, searching for causality. It's near incomprehensible at the time, but all very impactful. As the drug wears off you regain your logical faculties and continue reaching for causality before eventually attempting to reconcile your trip with reality and decide that the song about anal fisting is indeed deeply spiritual and nobody else understands brooooo.

This is the psychedelic experience. It's self induced emotional/existential trauma via a fake experience, the hippies that go into trips with "intentions" and "healing" are literally just trying to brainwash themselves into being happier with life by forcing themselves to have imaginary experiences which they believe will continue to permanently inform their perceptions of themselves and the world afterwards. This is also the basic principle behind what much of what the mkultra project was attempting to accomplish btw (implanting/reinforcing specific ideas and perceptions).

Why does nobody recommend doing weighted sit-ups at a mid rep range (10-12) to build ab muscles?

Why is high rep bodyweight sit-ups always shilled?

posts.name: Sage
posts.com:
>>69531006
Actually curious myself, I don't know if it has something to do with the type of muscle fiber, that they respond better to higher rep ranges as opposed to your typical hypertrophy 8-12 scheme. Someone will hopefully give a reasonable answer

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69531006
People are dumb and fall for old magazine snakeoil bullshit, that's all I can come up with. The only thing that makes the abs different from other muscles is the fact that they recover very quickly due to how often you use them, but this only impacts training frequency. They should still be trained like any other muscle, progressively overloading weight/reps instead of doing hundreds of reps every session that do literally nothing. Bodyweight shit still works, you just need to do the actual hard exercises (toes to bar leg raises, dragon flags, L-sits, ab wheel rollouts, etc). But they aren't inherently better than adding weight to something like situps.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69531046
As an addition to this I think that this stuff also lead to people shunning ab training as a whole with the whole muh squatz and deadz are enough for abs BS, because obviously doing thousands of crunches does literally nothing, but squats and deadlifts are not very good ab exercises at all, the abs simply act to increase intra-abdominal pressure and to help stabilize the spine a little during these movements, that's it. There's no spinal flexion or anti-extension going on because squats and deadlifts involve a high degree of anti-flexion, which is the opposite of what the abs are supposed to do. Literally almost all of the ab exercises in existence work the abs better than squats and deadlifts, in fact fucking OHP probably works them better because you start with a slightly extended thoracic spine which then flexes into neutral as you shove your head through the window, meaning your abs actually do a little bit of work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69531006
look into medicine ball exercises. You can get a much more well rounded workout and build strength, endurance, and explosiveness in the various directions that your abs can move.

So if I remember correctly, at the end of Ab Ripper X that 15 minute Tony Horton ab workout from P90X back in the day, he would do the Upward Dog Pose and follow it up with the Child's Pose. So you stretch both sides of your torso. With the Upward dog one, you can sort of lower your hips into the ground in order to feel more of a stretch. I like to go back and forth a few times instead of just one of each. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69524709
I know everyone shits on keto here, but it is an amazing tool to lose weight. I have been bodybuilding on and off for nearly a decade and I still have a lot of trouble adhering to a CICO diet. I'd strongly recommend Keto (really carnivore) and IF. If you are 200kg, you don't have the understanding of nutrition that is required to be successful using CICO.


If you are dead set on CICO, get the carb manager app and track EVERYTHING. And still do intermittent fasting, probably OMAD. It just makes tracking stuff so much easier and it will help alleviate hunger. Don't do a crazy deficit, Rome was not built in a day. Get to a point where you know what your maintenance is and slowly begin a deficit. You can start at like -300 cals but stay at a particular deficit for at least a week before trying to cut down more. Good Luck.

Are pre-workouts a scam placebo?

I am 100% natty and lift about 4 days per week for an hour and a half at a time, nothing crazy, I'm well beyond 1/2/3/4 stuff but not a bodybuilder or anything. For the past 3 months or so I've just been having a really hard time doing anything other than going through the motions at the gym, like I've been stuck at a plateau I'm having a hard time moving up from. My friend noticed this and suggested taking his pre-workout which was something in a very snake-oil looking plastic tub called "RYSE" or some bullshit like that.

So anyway, I said eh fuck it I'll try it out. Pushed well past my normal limits on every single exercise, didn't feel nearly as tired, felt like I recovered faster between sets, etc. The thing's full of a shitload of caffeine, which I don't drink anything like tea or coffee or soda, but I didn't feel like this stuff boosted me a huge amount, I felt perfectly normal aside from I was lifting much better.

Still, I'm ware and distrustful of stuff like this, I consider most of them to be expensive sugar, caffeine, or placebos (or all three). I don't really have any experience with this stuff though. Does or has anyone here take/taken a pre-workout, and is it a bunch of bullshit with diminishing returns over time? It would be nice to take it to help me push through this stupid plateau of gains I've been experiencing but I'm not convinced I need it to do that and it's not all just in my head.

The jogging might be why your squat and deadlift are abysmal - you are burning out your legs. Fast walking on an incline will suffice for cardio. If you really have to, do some sprint training once a week.
As I say, keep doing 5x5 until you are easily repping 1/2/3/4. Continue to read and learn, and when you get to that point, you will easily be able to put your own program together basing each day on a muscle group and compound appropriate to it (if you are looking to be strong and look good) or just do something like Texas or BBB if you want to concentrate more on strength.
Jumping from one program to another gets you no where, I know so many people who tell me on an almost weekly basis what program they have changed to now, and they never look any different. Be consistent with one program and you will look like you work out and improve strength,

>>69530820
a belt is helpful for bracing your core during heavy lifts. having something to brace against helps reduce the strain on your back and core when your lifting heavy in deadlifts or squats. you really shouldn't be using them unless your doing those types of lifts at a high level since it can significantly reduce the chances of injury. building your core muscles is more important but its in the same vein as lifting straps to assist your grip. you absolutely can just lift raw but for some people it helps significantly. I personally only use one during PR attempts to help mitigate strain. training your core takes precedence.

high carb diets are encouraged because in most places farmers that produce grains and corn are given huge subsidies to produce excessive amounts to make it cheap to feed our massive populations. not all carbs are bad, unprocessed carbs are a very good immediate energy source and have been a part of our historical diet for a very long time(whole grain breads, tubers, etc.) however modern food product carbs are mostly from things like highly processed subsidized corn byproducts and grains that prey on our natural inclinations to seek out high caloric content foods and produce a form of addiction for sweet foods. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69530148
Some people recommend trap-3 raises but I personally don't really like them that much, I do lower trap dips, you essentially just hold the lockout on a dip while letting the scapulae elevate on the negative then depressing them on the positive. Make sure you're not protracting at the top as that will recruit the pec minor, which isn't a bad thing as I think more people should train that muscle too, but it's a different exercise (pec minor dips as opposed to lower trap dips). I like these because they're extremely non-invasive, you can put them almost anywhere in your program in a superset/giantset with few issues. If this doesn't seem to do anything though then give the trap-3 raises a shot as for whatever reason everybody recommends them for lower traps. I'd also recommend some direct external rotator work if you're not doing them already (Facepulls do involve them but I MUCH prefer doing an isolated movement for the infraspinatus/teres minor because facepulls tend to be more rear delt dominant which isn't a bad thing necessarily but you could just do powell raises for that instead). Other than that I can recommend maybe trying some band dislocations and lu raises, but honestly I never did these consistently so I don't think they provide a ton of extra benefit, I'm just throwing out everything I've ever heard relating to shoulder issues. The final thing I can say is that it could just be the way you're doing the lift; I had some mild left shoulder pain from behind the neck press but I fixed it by learning how to force upward rotation of the scapula very early in the lift (just try to do the motion while trying to use your upper traps as much as possible to upwardly rotate and elevate your scapulae, you should feel them a lot even without holding any weight), now I have 0 shoulder discomfort doing BTNP to failure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69530148
>>69530854
For horizontal presses it could be that you're holding scapula retraction the entire time, from what I've heard the optimal way your scapula should be moving on horizontal presses is retraction on the negative, and protraction into neutral (if bench variation) or full protraction (pushup variation), so maybe you can try that and see if it resolves your shoulder issues. Since you're already doing incline db press this should be fairly easy as it's much easier to do this motion on an incline.

he's not wrong, I guess. Sometimes I don't have time and on a few occasions I end up getting fast food. I usually go to classes in the morning and I'm only home at 9pm. Obviously better planning and food prep will help, but for the times I'm tired, I am trying to buy microwave meals and simple stuff at the grocery store. These still are pretty bad, but I can get them cheaper than take out food, and generally they're a little healthier because I can check the ingredients and decide to buy the comparatively healthier options beforehand and keep them at home.

This way, if I'm in a situation where I might otherwise get food on the way home, I instead know I have something I can warm up and eat within 10 minutes and then go to bed.

At the next level, I try to replace those meals with real food. So I try to see what fast food outings I can turn into microwave dinners and see what microwave dinners I can replace with prepared normal food (ie chicken, vegetables, beans, etc.).

And for social settings I find that if I can have a snack like a banana, which is cheap and healthy, then I'm more filled and I'll get less food if I am stopping somewhere with somebody.

And I'm also trying to cook food for people in general because it's a nice thing to do. Restaurants are too expensive now, so if I make a plan to go to one then I figure it may as well be a nice sit-down place because I'd rather pay $25 for a real entree at a real restaurant than pay fucking 20 dollars for a sandwich at some mid tier joint because I guess that's how much they sell that for now.

Like I do not regret a candlelit dinner with a qt at all but I regret the times I bought shit and got ripped off at fast food or middling places

>>69530687
Powerlifting has weight classes because various heights can only put on so much muscle on their frames. And that's what weight classes effectively are, height classes. However, there's a reason that powerlifting competitions use DOTS/Wilks instead of bw multipliers, and that's because twinkshits have the advantage in those. A 200 lb person squatting 600 is much stronger than a 150 lb person squatting 450, even if they're "the same strength" by bw ratios.
